As 2025 draws to a close, Solana (SOL) finds itself at a crucial crossroads, shaped by both global economic trends and significant upgrades to its blockchain infrastructure. The platform’s future performance will depend on how effectively it adapts to changes in monetary policy and leverages its technical advancements. This overview explores the combined impact of these elements, referencing recent industry reports and institutional perspectives.
The Federal Reserve’s approach to monetary policy in the latter part of 2025 has played a pivotal role in influencing Solana’s market behavior. With the Fed adopting a more accommodative stance—halting interest rate increases and signaling a return to quantitative easing in early 2026—liquidity has flowed into riskier assets, boosting demand for cryptocurrencies such as SOL.
Industry analysis highlights that the Fed’s rate reduction in October 2025 prompted a surge in institutional investment. Notably, the Bitwise Solana ETF (BSOL) attracted $417 million in its initial phase, reflecting a broader trend of crypto assets being embraced as diversification tools, especially as traditional bond yields remain low.
Despite these positive developments, uncertainty around monetary policy continues to fuel volatility. For example, a 14% decline in Solana’s price in early November 2025 was linked to forced liquidations caused by delays in anticipated rate cuts and concerns over ongoing quantitative tightening. Nonetheless, historical patterns indicate that lower interest rates tend to make non-yielding assets like cryptocurrencies more attractive, a trend that was evident as Solana’s value climbed during the Fed’s gradual rate reductions in 2024 and 2025.
Institutional involvement has further strengthened Solana’s resilience to macroeconomic shifts. The introduction of regulated investment vehicles, such as the REX-Osprey Solana + Staking ETF, brought in $421 million in late 2025, underscoring confidence in Solana’s long-term prospects. These moves are part of a larger wave of crypto integration into mainstream finance, including retirement plans and exchange-traded products.
Solana’s technological progress in 2025 has solidified its reputation as a high-speed blockchain capable of rivaling established financial systems. The rollout of the Firedancer validator client and the Alpenglow consensus protocol has dramatically improved both scalability and efficiency. Firedancer, for instance, has slashed validator costs by 80% and diversified the network’s validator ecosystem, enhancing overall stability. Meanwhile, Alpenglow’s streamlined voting system has reduced block finality times to as little as 100–150 milliseconds, paving the way for real-time applications and high-frequency trading.
These upgrades are integral to Solana’s broader ambition to become a dominant force in global finance. By the end of 2025, the network’s total value locked (TVL) in decentralized finance reached $10.2 billion, supported by strategic collaborations such as those with Western Union for international payments. Developer participation has also soared, with over 17,700 active contributors utilizing innovative tools like Pinocchio and Token Extensions to drive further growth.
Market indicators point to a positive outlook for Solana. The cryptocurrency’s price has found support near $133, and technical signals—including the TD Sequential buy indicator and rising On-Balance Volume (OBV)—suggest potential gains toward the $150–$165 range by year’s end. Past events, such as the 400% rally following the Token-22 upgrade in 2024, reinforce this optimistic perspective.
While Solana’s advancements on both the technical and institutional fronts enhance its durability, certain risks remain. Persistent inflation or a shift in the Fed’s policy direction could dampen appetite for risk assets. Macro Liquidity and Fed Policy Shape Solana’s 2025 Trajectory
The macroeconomic backdrop remains the dominant force behind Solana (SOL-USD) price behavior in late 2025. Following the Federal Reserve’s conclusion of its multi-year quantitative tightening (QT) program, global liquidity dynamics have shifted decisively. The Fed’s transition toward easing — after maintaining restrictive policy between 2023 and mid-2025 — has begun injecting liquidity back into markets. This shift historically benefits risk assets, especially those with strong transactional ecosystems like Solana.
During the QT phase, the crypto sector lost an estimated 15% of total market value, with liquidity constrained and speculative flows diverted toward Bitcoin and stablecoins. Solana’s ecosystem, heavily dependent on capital efficiency and on-chain throughput, saw trading volatility surge while institutional inflows dried up. However, as of December 2025, post-QT liquidity injections have turned net-positive, producing the first expansionary macro environment since early 2022. This shift aligns with Solana’s recent stabilization above $132 and the reduction in downside momentum after weeks of heavy selling.
Structural Market Compression Around $132 Reflects Indecision Before Breakout
Solana’s price has consolidated tightly between $130 and $145, reflecting a market in equilibrium following months of volatility. The SOL-USD pair currently trades near $135.66, up 2.7% daily, as buyers defend a critical horizontal range that defines the lower boundary of its multi-month trading structure.

Each approach toward this band since 2023 has generated rebounds of 30–45%, confirming its role as the backbone of the long-term uptrend. Market depth data indicates large resting bids between $125 and $127, reinforcing the probability of stabilization if the range is retested.
Descending Wedge and Historical Trendline Define the Long-Term Setup

The wedge has guided all major corrections since early 2024, with repeated tests of its lower band. The upper boundary near $150–$155 marks the inflection zone that could confirm a new breakout if reclaimed with volume.
Price currently rests on the same diagonal trendline that supported every major recovery since 2023, including rebounds from $8 in late 2022, $21 in mid-2023, and $65 in early 2024. A clean bounce from this structure would sustain the long-term bullish trajectory toward $180–$200. source_articles.body:
LIVE UPDATES
Stock futures are near flat on Sunday night, following another winning week for Wall Street, as investors look toward the Federal Reserve meeting.
Dow Jones Industrial Average futures added 35 points, or 0.2%. S&P 500 futures and Nasdaq 100 futures each also rose 0.1%.
Sunday night's action comes after a second positive week in a row for the three major indexes. The Dow and Nasdaq Composite added 0.5% and 0.9%, respectively, in the week.
The S&P 500 added around 0.3% last week, bringing the broad index about 0.7% off its all-time intraday high. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq also notched four-day winning streaks on Friday, while the Dow has been positive in three of the last four sessions.
Stocks received a boost on Friday after the delayed release of September's core personal consumption expenditures price index came in softer than economists anticipated. That was one of the last major economic releases ahead of the Fed's policy gathering taking place this week.
Traders have grown increasingly hopeful over recent weeks that the Fed will lower interest rates at the Federal Open Market Committee meeting, which is the final one of the year. Fed funds futures are pricing in a roughly 88% chance of a decrease, up from under 67% a month ago, according to CME's FedWatch tool.
"Markets are appropriately focused on an interest rate cut or hold coming out of ... [the] FOMC meeting," Eric Freedman, Northern Trust's chief investment officer for wealth management, wrote to clients. But, "investors are perhaps more interested in dynamics surrounding voting-member outlooks and future Fed leadership."
There is no economic data of note due Monday, but the New York Fed is releasing its survey of consumer expectations in the morning. Investors will keep an eye on earnings from companies such as Lululemon, Costco, Broadcom, Oracle and Adobe slated for this week.
CRH, Carvana and Comfort Systems will join the S&P 500 beginning Dec. 22, S&P Global announced Friday.
U.S.-listed shares of CRH, the Irish materials maker, jumped more than 6% in extended trading. Shares of used car sales platform Carvana and HVAC provider Comfort Systems added more than 9% and 1%, respectively.
S&P Global said the trio would replace LKQ, Solstice Advanced Materials and Mohawk Industries.
— Alex Harring
Futures tied to the Dow, S&P 500 and Nasdaq 100 all traded around flat shortly after 6 p.m. ET Sunday night.
— Alex Harring

source_articles.title: Entrepreneur who backed Labour shuts business over ‘economic uncertainty’ - AOL.com
source_articles.body:
Entrepreneur who backed Labour shuts business over ‘economic uncertainty’
An entrepreneur who backed Labour at the last election has closed his business, blaming escalating costs and “economic uncertainty”.
Ben Govier, the owner of Dylan’s Ice Cream, which has parlours in Surrey and Hampshire, said he was shutting because the business environment had “simply become unsustainable”.
Mr Govier was one of 120 company chiefs who in May last year signed a letter backing Keir Starmer’s agenda for business just weeks before the general election.
The letter claimed that Labour had “shown it has changed and wants to work with business to achieve the UK’s full potential”.
It added that companies needed a government that would “partner fiscal discipline with a long-term growth strategy, working in partnership with the private sector to drive innovation and investment to build digital and physical capital and fix our skills system”.
Other signatories included Andy Palmer, the former chief executive of Aston Martin, and TV chef Tom Kerridge.
Announcing the closure of his business “for the time being”, Mr Govier said on Instagram that the “last couple of years have presented significant challenges”.
He said: “For a specialist, seasonal business like Dylan’s, the operating environment has simply become unsustainable.
Advertisement
“Covid and the subsequent shifts in the market, the endless price increases of our raw materials and the ongoing lasting impact of economic uncertainty have created hurdles that even the most resilient businesses have struggled to overcome.”
He said the decision to shut after 17 years had been “incredibly disappointing”. The closure was first reported by the Mail on Sunday.
The entrepreneur warned earlier this year that costs for milk powder, cocoa, electricity and staff had increased so much that he was failing to make money.
News of the closure comes as businesses reel from the impact of Labour’s Budget. Companies cut jobs at the fastest pace since July 2021 last month as they battled rising labour costs.
Businesses had repeatedly warned of job losses after Rachel Reeves, the Chancellor, raised employers’ National Insurance contributions in her maiden Budget last year, alongside increases in the minimum wage.
Around 3,500 retail properties will also pay an extra £112m in business rates from next April as a result of changes announced in Ms Reeves’s second Budget last month, according to tax consultants Ryan. The British Independent Retailers Association estimates that a typical shop owner will see their bill rise by 15pc next year.
It has sparked warnings that Britain’s high streets risk being further hollowed out in the coming years as more firms go bust.

source_articles.title: Starmer to back Budget after Reeves accused of misleading public - AOL.com
source_articles.body:
Starmer to back Budget after Reeves accused of misleading public
Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer will give his backing to the chancellor's Budget in a speech on Monday, and commit the government to going "further and faster" on pro-growth measures.
He will say Chancellor Rachel Reeves's statement will help to alleviate cost of living pressures, lower inflation and ensure economic stability.
It comes as the Treasury faces questions over whether it was transparent about the state of the public finances in the run-up to the Budget.
The Conservatives claimed Reeves misled the public by being too pessimistic about the economic outlook when official forecasts painted a more upbeat picture.
No 10 has denied that Reeves misled voters and defended her statement.
Despite the Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) downgrading growth from next year, the prime minister will argue that "economic growth is beating forecasts", but the government must do more to encourage it.
Protecting investment and public services will further drive financial growth, Sir Keir is expected to say.
The prime minister will also promise to cut "unnecessary red tape" in infrastructure after a report found the UK had become the most expensive place in the world to build nuclear power infrastructure.
Advertisement
He will call for reform in the sector and an urgent correction to "fundamentally misguided environmental regulation".
Business Secretary Peter Kyle is to be tasked with applying the lessons of the nuclear power report to infrastructure more widely.
The prime minister's speech on Monday, just five days after the Budget, may suggest some nervousness over how the government's economic plans have been received by the public, though No 10 say a statement was already planned.
In the days since the Budget, Downing Street has been forced to publicly back Reeves after she was accused by political opponents of repeatedly warning about a downgrade to the UK's economic productivity forecasts, paving the way for tax hikes.
In a letter to MPs sent on Friday, the chairman of the OBR revealed that he told the chancellor on 17 September that the public finances were in better shape than widely thought.
The Conservatives have accused Reeves of giving an overly pessimistic impression of the public finances as a "smokescreen" to raise taxes.
Tory leader Kemi Badenoch said the letter showed Reeves had "lied to the public" and should be sacked.
Last week, a spokesperson for the Treasury said: "We are not going to get into the OBR's processes or speculate on how that relates to the internal decision‑making in the build‑up to a Budget, but the chancellor made her choices to cut the cost of living, cut hospital waiting lists and double headroom to cut the cost of our debt."
Both the chancellor and Badenoch are scheduled to appear on the BBC's Sunday with Laura Kuenssberg programme.

source_articles.title: Was Budget 'the right thing' or 'deeply frustrating'? - AOL.com
source_articles.body:
Was Budget 'the right thing' or 'deeply frustrating'?
An increase in the minimum wage, a three-year freeze on income tax thresholds, tax surcharge on properties worth more than £2m and scrapping the two-child benefit cap were among the main announcements in the Budget.
Chancellor Rachel Reeves insisted she would not "lose control" of public spending with "reckless borrowing".
She told the House of Commons earlier that she would take "fair and necessary choices" for the economy, to bring down NHS waiting lists, the national debt and the cost of living.
Politicians, businesses, employees, pensioners and families in the south of England have been giving their reactions to the announcements.
In the hospitality sector, many had hoped for a cut in VAT that did not appear.
But Reeves announced a reduction in business rates for retail, hospitality and leisure properties.
Basingstoke pub landlord Darren Head said: "I hoped maybe there would be a shining light that actually the government would do something to support local businesses and pubs, but sadly it looks like its business as usual.
"On the positive side of things, we're not going to be hit worse."
Workers aged between 18-20 will see a minimum wage increase to £10.85 an hour, up from £10, and those aged 21 and over on the living wage will receive £12.71 an hour, up from £12.21.
Teenagers aged 16 or 17 on the minimum wage will be paid £8 an hour - a 45p raise.
Thresholds for National Insurance paid by employers were also frozen until 2031, increasing costs as wages rise over time.
Sam Sheldon, co-owner of the Riptide Espresso & Records café in Poole, said the rise in National Insurance payments would "really affect" her business, which relied on part-time staff.
"The more people we hire, obviously the more national insurance we have to pay," she said.
"We feel like things just go up for us every year - you just expect it now and we just have to put our prices up."
The budget was the main topic of conversation at the Moordown Community Centre in Bournemouth.
The chancellor announced National Insurance and income tax thresholds would be frozen for an extra three years beyond 2028, dragging more people into higher bands over time.
Pensioner Jeff, who was playing kurling at the centre, said news that the triple lock on state pensions would be maintained was "very good for me".
The triple lock guarantees that the pension will increase by at least 2.5% and will rise in line with, or faster than, inflation or average wages.
He said: "But the freeze on the income tax threshold will affect me and is not so good.
"In my opinion they give it to us with one hand and take it away with the other."
Another player, Judy, said she found herself in the same position following the pension increase.
"It just puts me into the tax bracket," she said. "I wasn't paying it before and now I am."
Another member, Carol said the minimum wage going up but tax thresholds staying the same would not help her sons and grandsons who own painting and decorating businesses.
Advertisement
"I don't think it's going to help them at all - there were so many taxes etc that keep getting thrown at small businesses," she said.
"They couldn't afford to take anybody on."
Debbie, a singing teacher at the centre, said there was "a lot of positive things" that came out in the budget but it was "disappointing" for the arts.
James Talbot, co-founder of the HARE chain of hairdressing and skincare salons in Oxfordshire, said he was "deeply frustrated by the lack of meaningful support" for businesses.
He said: "Once again, one of the country's most socially important and economically vulnerable sectors has been overlooked and ignored.
"The rise in the minimum wage, while well-intentioned, will hit small legal businesses like ours hard at a time when margins are already razor-thin."
He said that although helpful, the "details remain unclear" about the introduction of lower business rates for retail.

US stock futures held steady Sunday evening as Wall Street heads into a pivotal week dominated by the Federal Reserve's final policy meeting of 2025.
Futures tied to the Dow Jones Industrial Average (YM=F), the S&P 500 (ES=F), and Nasdaq 100 (NQ=F) all hovered around the flatline.
(YM=F)
The modest moves followed on the heels of a back-to-back weeks of gains for the major gauges. The S&P 500 (^GSPC) rose 0.3% last week, with the Dow (^DJI) and Nasdaq Composite (^IXIC) advancing 0.5% and 0.9% respectively. Markets were buoyed by a tame PCE reading for September that indicated a muted impact to "core" expenses.
The week ahead brings a raft of economic releases, chief of which is the meeting of Federal Reserve rate-setters on Tuesday. The public has been keenly eyeing the Fed ahead of Wednesday’s announcement and press conference from Chair Jerome Powell, with confidence in a rate-cut reaching optimistic highs.
Expectations for a rate cut have surged recently, with Fed funds futures now implying an 88% probability of an easing move, sharply higher than the sub-67% odds seen a month ago, per CME FedWatch.
The labor market will also be in the spotlight after a mixed bag of data last week. Tuesday finally brings the postponed October JOLTS report offering a read on hiring activity, layoffs, and the pace at which workers are quitting.
On the earnings side, Oracle (ORCL) and Adobe (ADBE) quarterly results will be in focus on Wednesday, while Broadcom (AVGO) and Costco (COST) headline the proceedings on Thursday.

source_articles.title: Navy releases ‘catastrophic’ findings involving USS Harry S. Truman - Navy Times
source_articles.body:
The U.S. Navy released summaries for four separate investigations into incidents that involved the USS Harry S. Truman between December 2024 and May 2025.
The investigation looked into the Truman’s collision with a merchant vessel, along with the loss of three F/A-18 Super Hornets.
“These investigations assessed underlying procedural compliance and standards and reviewed how a Carrier Strike Group prepares for and responds to adversity during combat operations,” the investigation summary read.
Vice Chief of Naval Operations Adm. James Kilby vowed that the service would learn from the incidents, especially in light of the investigation’s findings.
Kilby added that the Navy would continue to invest in its service members to ensure they were ready for future challenges.
The USS Harry S. Truman collided with the merchant vessel Besiktas-M on Feb. 12 near Port Said, Egypt. No injuries or flooding were reported.
RELATED
Shortly after, the service relieved Capt. Dave Snowden, commanding officer of the USS Harry S. Truman, due to a loss of confidence in his ability to command.
The investigation found that the collision was avoidable and that the “carrier’s bridge team failed to safely navigate past the merchant vessel.”
Regarding the collision, the incident “could have caused catastrophic results,” the report concluded.
Between December 2024 and May 2025, the USS Harry S. Truman Carrier Strike Group was plagued with errors involving jets that each costs approximately $60 million.
The USS Gettysburg shot down an F/A-18F Super Hornet in December 2024 in an act of friendly fire, an F/A-18F Super Hornet attempting to land on the USS Harry S. Truman in May toppled overboard and an F/A-18E Super Hornet fighter jet fell off the hangar deck of the Truman in April.
The investigation found that the friendly fire incident resulted from misidentification that stemmed from a “lack of integrated training opportunities between USS Gettysburg and the Carrier Strike Group, lack of forceful backup on the cruiser, and lack of cohesion across the Carrier Strike Group.”
The April incident in which the jet and a tow tractor fell from Truman’s hangar bay occurred as a result of evasive maneuvers in response to an incoming ballistic missile in the Red Sea, the summary stated. The investigation attributed the jet’s loss to an aircraft brake system failure, as well as poor communication between the bridge, flight deck control and hangar bay control.
The investigation further found that the failed landing of an F/A-18 that forced two pilots to eject in May arose from a failure of the #4 arresting wire aboard Truman that resulted from “a malfunctioning #4 starboard sheave damper.”
The report also cited inadequate maintenance practices, low manning levels, limited knowledge, insufficient training, high operational tempo and combat conditions as catalysts for the incident.
Riley Ceder is a reporter at Military Times, where he covers breaking news, criminal justice, investigations, and cyber. He previously worked as an investigative practicum student at The Washington Post, where he contributed to the Abused by the Badge investigation.

source_articles.title: Roster Moves: Jaguars Activate S Eric Murray From IR, Elevate Two Players and Waive One - Jaguars.com
source_articles.body:
JACKSONVILLE – The Jacksonville Jaguars have made the following roster moves, the team announced today:
- Activated S Eric Murray from the Reserve/Injured; Designated for Return list
- Waived RB Cody Schrader
- Elevated DB Cam'Ron Silmon-Craig and WR Austin Trammell to the active roster from the practice squad for tomorrow's game via standard elevation
Murray started the first seven games of the season before being placed on the Reserve/Injured list on October 31. He totaled 33 tackles (18 solo), four passes defensed, an interception and a quarterback hit.
Silmon-Craig joined the Jaguars as an undrafted free agent out of Colorado this offseason. He has played in each of the last two games as a standard elevation. Silmon-Craig started all 13 games for the Buffaloes during his final collegiate season in 2024, leading the team with 93 total tackles (10 for loss) to go with three passes defensed, two fumble recoveries, 2.0 sacks, one forced fumble and one interception.
Trammell has appeared in each of the last five games for Jacksonville and has spent the last two seasons with the team, splitting time between the active roster and practice squad. He has appeared in 30 career games and totaled 11 receptions for 128 yards in five seasons with the Falcons (2021), Rams (2022-23) and Jaguars (2024-25). He has also returned 27 punts for 190 yards and seven kickoffs for 155 yards in his career.

source_articles.title: The Nikkei Average edged down by 18 yen, marking a slight continued decline, as heavyweight semiconductor-related stocks struggled, while the TOPIX rose in the morning session eight days ago. - 富途牛牛
source_articles.body:
In the morning session eight days ago, the Nikkei Stock Average fell by 18 yen and 3 sen from the previous Friday to 50,473.84 yen, marking a slight continued decline. Meanwhile, the TOPIX (Tokyo Stock Price Index) rebounded, rising by 13.87 points to 3,376.43 points. In early trading, the Nikkei Average initially saw buying interest but was pressured by profit-taking, leading to a downturn. At 9:06 AM, it hit an intraday low of 50,224.65 yen, down by 267.22 yen. Thereafter, buying on dips helped limit further declines. However, semiconductor-related stocks, including Advantest (6857.T) and Tokyo Electron (8035.T), which had previously led gains, lost momentum, weighing on the index. The revised GDP figures for the July-September quarter, released before the market opened, showed a 2.3% contraction on an annualized basis, worse than the market consensus of a 2.0% decline, but the reaction was muted. The dollar-yen exchange rate hovered around 154.90 yen per dollar, showing some appreciation in the yen compared to early morning levels.
The trading volume in the Tokyo Stock Exchange Prime Market reached 992.21 million shares, with a total trading value of 2.4655 trillion yen. Among listed issues, 1,228 stocks advanced while only 321 declined, indicating more gainers than losers. An additional 59 stocks remained unchanged.
By sector, declines were limited to just five out of the 33 industry groups, while 28 sectors posted gains. Bank stocks such as Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (8306.T) and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group (8316.T), along with retail stocks like Seven & i Holdings (3382.T) and AEON (8267.T), saw declines. Information and communication stocks, including SoftBank Group (9984.T), and other product stocks like Nintendo (7974.T), as well as petroleum and coal stocks such as ENEOS Holdings (5020.T) and Cosmo Energy Holdings (5021.T), also traded lower. On the other hand, real estate stocks such as Mitsui Fudosan (8801.T) and Mitsubishi Estate (8802.T), as well as nonferrous metal stocks like Sumitomo Electric Industries (5802.T) and Fujikura (5803.T), rose. Construction stocks like Obayashi Corporation (1802.T) and Shimizu Corporation (1803.T), as well as warehouse and transportation stocks like Mitsubishi Logistics (9301.T) and Mitsui Warehouse Co., Ltd. (9302.T), also performed strongly. Pulp and paper stocks such as Oji Holdings (3861.T) and Nippon Paper Industries (3863.T), as well as land transport stocks like East Japan Railway Company (9020.T) and Central Japan Railway Company (9022.T), remained firm.
Elsewhere, Osaka Titanium Technologies (5726.T), W Scope (6619.T), Japan Air Conditioning Service (4658.T), Nitto Boseki (3110.T), and Nichiei (2353.T) saw declines. Conversely, Nippon Shinyaku (4516.T), Focus Corporation (4662.T), KLab (3656.T), Tsukishima Kikai (6332.T), and Kagaku Kikai (6331.T) posted gains.

source_articles.title: Japan's Nikkei edges lower, big tech shares drag amid valuation worries - TradingView
source_articles.body:
Japan's Nikkei edges lower, big tech shares drag amid valuation worries
By Kevin Buckland
Japan's Nikkei share average edged lower on Monday, weighed by tech stocks amid continued investor caution about sky-high valuations for artificial intelligence-related shares.
At the same time, a more stable yen after a bout of strength in recent weeks supported the broader market, even with rising market bets for a Bank of Japan interest rate hike next week. Gains for Wall Street on Friday provided an additional tailwind.
The Nikkei NI225 declined less than 0.1% to 50,473.84 as of the midday recess. The broader Topix TOPIX, by contrast, added 0.4% to 3,376.43.
The biggest drag on the Nikkei was startup investor SoftBank Group 9984, shaving 93 points from the index with a 2.5% slide. Next was chip-testing equipment maker Advantest 6857, which fell 0.9%, followed by chip-making machinery manufacturer Tokyo Electron 8035, which lost 1%, subtracting a combined 79 points from the index.
"There's a sense of overheating in high-tech stocks, making them susceptible to selling pressure," said Fumika Shimizu, an equities strategist at Nomura Securities.
"The underlying trend of falling tech stocks remains intact."
Overall, though, winners vastly outnumbered losers on the Nikkei, with 162 of its 225 components rising, 59 falling, and four trading flat.
The index rose to a record high of 52,636.87 in early November before succumbing to profit-taking, centered on AI-related shares.
"The Nikkei feels heavy," said Masahiro Ichikawa, chief market strategist at Sumitomo Mitsui DS Asset Management.
"For the time being, I expect stocks to trade sideways. A rise from here would come with high risk."
Despite the fall in chip-related shares, stocks tied to expectations of increased demand for data centers were among the top performers on the Nikkei. Fujikura 5803 soared 5.7% and Fuji Electric 6504 jumped 4.1%.
The best-performing sector among the Tokyo Stock Exchange's 33 industry groups was real estate RE, which climbed 2.6%.
Banking TTOPIXB lost 0.7% to be the bottom performer, but that was after rising to the highest level since 1999 last week on expectations the BOJ will resume hiking rates.

source_articles.title: Tech Drags On The Nikkei While Real Estate Shines - Finimize
source_articles.body:
Japanese tech shares slipped as investors locked in profits, but real estate stocks helped balance out the Nikkei’s performance for the day.
about 2 hours ago • 2 mins
Join the newsletter that everyone in finance secretly reads. 1M+ subscribers, 100% free.
What’s going on here?
Japan’s Nikkei slid 0.2% to close at 32,800, as profit-taking hit high-flying tech shares and real estate stocks kept steeper declines at bay.
What does this mean?
Japanese tech shares—especially those tied to artificial intelligence—lost some shine after the Nikkei’s stellar November performance. SoftBank Group led the fall with a 2.5% drop, weighing on the index, while high-valuation chip and AI names like Advantest and Tokyo Electron also declined, knocking off 79 points from the Nikkei. That said, the broader market showed underlying strength: 162 out of 225 stocks actually gained on the day, helped by a rally in real estate stocks and solid results from firms like Fujikura and Fuji Electric riding the data center boom. A steady yen and positive sentiment from Wall Street offered some support, but caution is growing, with market strategists flagging the risk of overheating in certain tech segments and predicting sideways trading ahead.
Why should I care?
For markets: Tech fatigue cools the rally.
Profit-taking in major AI-focused stocks is tapping the brakes on a red-hot sector and casting doubt on whether tech valuations can keep rising after such big leaps. Real estate shares are stepping up as the new source of momentum, balancing out the market as money shifts to less stretched sectors. This rotation may keep the Nikkei’s short-term moves in check, with many investors taking a cautious approach after recent surges.
The bigger picture: Rotation highlights broader caution.
Investors piling into real estate suggests a search for stability and diversification away from overheated tech names. Muted moves in banking stocks—even as market watchers expect a possible Bank of Japan rate hike—add another layer of hesitation. Altogether, Japan’s market is echoing global trends: investors are tiptoeing toward safer, value-driven plays, aware of the risks tied to interest rate shifts and a still-sensitive currency.
